slidelink.displaytext: Samples, IV, & DV for Research Question

slidetranscripts.slidetranscript: Hello everyone! Welcome to the lecture on research problems and questions.

This lecture has four objectives:

First, Identify components of research problems

Second, understand what variables are

Third, Formulate research questions for quantitative research, and

Fourth, Frame research questions for qualitative research

There are many issues facing us in education. Have you ever wonder about which is more effective, directed instruction or inquiry-based learning? Why some kids are just not motivated to learn? What contribute to inequality in education?

Identifying a research problem is the first step in conducing educational research. How do we come up with good research problems and questions? Let’s find out!

Identifying a research problem is like putting puzzles together. You ask many questions until you can identify a good research problem that can be empirically investigated to make a contribution to the field. What are the sources for identifying research problems?

Sometimes research problems come from our questioning of accepted educational practice or intuition to challenge common sense. For example, why should there be different grade levels? Why should students attend 180 days of school, why not 200 days? By questioning existing practices can help to generate good research problems.

Oftentimes, we found research problems because we have encountered problems or we have a vest interest in a certain topic. It may be a topic that you are curious about or a topic that emerges after a discussion with a colleague. Your interests and experiences could be a good source for research problems.

Theories are common sources for identifying a research problem. We test, revise, or clarify existing theory by applying it to a education setting to see if it works. Some researchers want to test a theory. Other researchers want to develop and change a theory. For example, Maslow’s hierarchy of needs explains patterns of human motivation moving from physiological needs, safety needs, love and belongingness needs, esteem needs, to self-actualization. Will this theory work in different culture or can it be modified for different cultures?

Another way to identify research problems is based on empirical studies from previous research or investigation of contradictory findings. We can also replicate a research to see if it will work in a different setting.
Now, pause for a minute and take out a piece of paper and write down a few research problems you have identified.
Typically, a research problem consists of the following three components: context, significance, and purpose.

Context refers to the background or setting being investigated. For example, a research might say, “There has been growing interest in the assessment of digital literacy of K-12 learners,” or “For the past decade, researchers have been investigating the effectiveness of one-to-one learning with mobile devices.” The context is usually included in the beginning of a research paper.

Here is one example of context description:

Community colleges currently enroll about 34% of US undergraduates, a disproportionate share of them from low-income families. At least half of these students will fail to earn a college credential, and success rates are even lower for students deemed in need of remediation.

The researchers explain the backdrop of this research and highlight where the problems lie.

The second component of a research problem is the purpose. Now we have identified the context of the problem, what would be the purpose of conducting a research to understand an issue better? It is important to lay out the purpose of a research so that readers can understand why a research conducted a study.

A research problem typically begins as a general topic and ends with a more specific statement of purpose. A good topic might be teacher evaluation. You could start with this as something you’d like to study, make an argument for why the research is needed, then identify what specific aspects of teacher evaluation need to be investigated. All of this is conveyed in the first few paragraphs of the study, using references as appropriate as support and justification for the importance of researching the issue.

Here are a few examples of beginning phrases:

• The purpose of this study is…

• The aim of the current investigation…

• In this study, we investigated…

• The goal of the research was to…

Significance explains the reason or need for this study, why is it important to conduct this research? The significance of a study can be a contribution to professional literature or a contribution to practice. Oftentimes a researcher will point out that there is a gap in the literature on what’s been researched and what we still don’t know. The significance of a study is to remedy the deficiency or the gap.

Here’s one example of stating the significance of a study.

Understanding the factors that improve teacher motivation in low-performing schools…contributes to a broader knowledge based around improving teacher performance, and, as a result, student performance.
In quantitative research, when you have identified the research problem and conducted literature review, the next step is to present problem statements and research questions.

Before asking a research question, we need to have a good understanding of variables.

A variable is a name that represents a concept. Variables provide the kind of clarity for asking a good research questions. For examples, social economic status can be divided into three levels, high, middle, or low. School grade levels, age groups, race are all examples of variables.

There are two ways to define a variable. A conceptual definition (sometimes called constitutive definition) is the dictionary definition. We use words, not always very precise, to describe the variable. For example,, Attitude is defined as a predisposition to respond favorably or unfavorably toward a person, object, or event. They are important for researchers to communicate what is being investigated but not always measurable.

An operational definition is usually how a concept is measured or manipulated. For example, Socioeconomic status (SES) is defined by parents’ self-report of average monthly income.

Well-defined variables are important for composing a research question. In this example of research question, “Do exercise increase academic performance?” There are two variables; exercises and academic performance. A researcher needs to be able to define what ”exercise” and “academic performance” mean so a specific research problem can be investigated.
Here are some more examples of conceptual definitions and operational definitions of different variables. You can pause your video to read them.

Next we want to introduce you to two important concepts, independent variables and dependent variables. We use independent variables to influence the dependent variables and examine the results. In an experiment, the independent variable is the intervention and the dependent variable is the student outcomes. Another example of independent variable could be school size and the dependent variable could be student behavior. Do larger schools have more issues with student behaviors?

In this research question, “Do exercise lead to better academic performance?” The independent variable is the amount of exercise in a week. Dependent variables could be student grades.

To reach internal validity of an experiment, we need to make sure that the independent variable really caused changes in the dependent variable. Sometimes, there are other variables that may contribute to the outcomes of an experiment.

For example, to study the effect of screen time on eyesight, screen time is the independent variable and eyesight is the dependent variable. Other factors such as lighting in the room or types of mobile devices uses might also affect eyesight that we might have to take into consideration.
Other variables include confounding variable, extraneous variable, moderating variable, and mediating variable.

A confounding variable is the one that systematically changes with the independent variable and may affect dependent variables.

For example:

Two classrooms are used in a study to compare a new teaching method. One teacher uses the traditional approach, the other uses the new method. The teaching methods are the independent variables and student performance will be dependent variables. Teacher would be a confounding variable because the style, personality, and knowledge of the teachers differ.

Extraneous variables are variables present in the experiment that aren’t being studied. Extraneous variables may affect the dependent variables but is either unknown or not controlled by the researcher. Extraneous variables are conditions, events, features, or outcomes that target a specific group, are not part of the study that influence the individuals in the group and, like a confounding variable, may affect the results. For example, if a few students in one of the classes in a study get sick, this may affect the study results.

The problem with extraneous variables is that the may or may not affect the dependent variables. We don’t know until the end of an experiment.

Variables that may increase or decrease the relationship between the independent and independent variables. For example, in this new teaching method, girls may improve significantly if there are more collaboration opportunities.

Variables that helps explain how or why an intervention causes a change in the dependent variable. For example, a teaching method (or intervention) might challenge students more and increase their motivation in learning, which, in turn, affects student performance.

In formulating a research problem, keep these in mind:

o The problem should be researchable: A researchable problem is one that can be answered empirically by collecting and analyzing data.

o The problem should be important: The results of research need to have theoretical or practical significance. Theoretical importance is determined by the contribution of the study to knowledge as presented in existing literature. Do the results add new knowledge or change the way we understand phenomena? Practical importance implies that the results can be used immediately in routine educational practice.

o They should indicate the type of research: The research question should be clear if the study involves a simple description, a comparison, a relationship, or a difference. For example, for relationship question, we can ask “what is the relationship of mobile screen time and children’s eyesight?” for comparison question, we can ask “how do male and female differ in their self-concept of math knowledge?”

The problem typically begins as a general topic and ends with a more specific statement of purpose. A good topic might be teacher evaluation. You could start with this as something you’d like to study, make an argument for why the research is needed, then identify what specific aspects of teacher evaluation need to be investigated. All of this is conveyed in the first few paragraphs of the study, using references as appropriate as support and justification for the importance of researching the issue. Here’s one example. Pause the video to read it.

Now we have learned the definitions and types of variables. What are their purposes in assisting you in formulating research problems and questions. In quantitative research, the research question should clearly include specific samples and variables. For examples in this research question: To what extent do elementary teachers differ in their referral rate of suspension of minority students as a result of a 30-hour culturally-responsive teaching program?

The elementary teachers are the samples, suspension referral rate is the dependent variable, and culturally-responsive training is the independent variable.

Here are a comparison of non-researchable questions and researchable questions.

“Should the school days be longer?” This question has not clearly defined variables. A better way to ask the question is: “What is the relationship between length of the school day and SAT scores of high school students?” In this question, we know the sample is the “high school students.” The independent variable is “length of school days” and the dependent variable is “SAT scores.”

Another example: “Should students with disabilities be included in regular English classes as well as in physical education?” This is not really searchable.

Let’s try this:

“What is the effect of inclusion of fourth-grade students with learning disabilities into regular English classes on the self-concept, attitudes, and achievements?”

Now you decide what the sample, IV, and DV are. Write down your answer before moving to the next slide.

Now check your answer again the answer on the slide.

The sample population is the fourth grade students with learning disabilities.

The independent variable is the inclusive English classrooms.

The dependent variables are self-concept, attitudes, and achievements which can be measured using validated instruments.

In quantitative research, researchers often conduct research to test a hypothesis. A research hypothesis is a conceptual, declarative restatement of the research question that indicates the results the investigator expects to find.

o Hypotheses serve a number of important purposes in quantitative studies. The purposes include:

• Provide a focus that integrates information

• Provide a statement of relationships that are testable

• Allow the researcher to confirm or disconfirm a theory

• Can provide evidence of the predictive nature of the relationship between variables

• Provide a framework

Here are some examples of research questions and the corresponding research hypotheses.

Let’s look at the first one:

“Does mothers’ and fathers’ SES predict their teaching of reading and mathematics during kindergarten and Grade 1?”

The research question can be translated into the following hypothesis:

“Mothers and fathers with low SES would show more teaching of reading and mathematics than those with higher SES.”

It’s the norm to include both research questions and hypotheses in quantitative research methods.

The logic and purpose differ from those in quantitative research. In qualitative research, the research questions are:

• Open-ended

• Evolving

• Process oriented

• Use words such as generate, understand, and explore

• No predictions or expected results

The problem statement/question should…

• Not be too general nor too specific

• Be amenable to change as data are collected

• Not be biased with researcher assumptions

• Be written using “how” and “what” to keep the focus on description

• Include the central phenomenon and an indication of the participants and the study site

• Use language that conveys the nature of the design

Pause your video to read an example of a problem statement and research questions from an actual research.

Pause your video to read an example of a problem statement and research questions from an actual research. Talk to experienced researcher or stakeholders in your research on ways to refine the problem statement and research questions. Reading previous studies from reputable refereed journals is also an excellent way to develop your craft.

Here’s a quick summary of this lecture.

In this lecture, we discussed:

1. How to identify a research problem and its components

2. Different types of variables

3. How to formulate the research questions for both quantitative and qualitative research methods
